document.docAuthor: Barahona-Segovia, Rodrigo M., Riera, Pamela, Pañinao-Monsálvez, Laura, Guzmán, Vicente Valdés & Henríquez-Piskulich, Patricia
document.masterDocTitle: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Updating the knowledge of the flower flies (Diptera: Syrphidae) from Chile: Illustrated catalog, extinction risk and biological notes

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURES 134–139. Copestylum rufoscutellare (Philippi, 1865): (134) lateral view and (135) dorsal view, male (Photos by Vicente Valdés). Scale bars = 1.5 mm. Copestylum saphirinum (Bigot, 1883): (136) lateral view, female (photo by Vicente Valdés). Scale bar = 2 mm. Copestyllum scutellata (Macquart, 1842): (137) lateral view (photo by Vicente Valdés). Scale bar = 3 mm. (138) feeding on Porlieria chilensis I. M. Johnst., Alcones (photo by Esteban López), and (139) feeding on Prunus sp., Santiago (photo by Orlando Montes).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Type locality and data.
“ Chile ” (T, ♂ , MNHNP )
.

World distribution. Argentina , Brazil , Peru and Chile .
Chilean distribution. From Arica y Parinacota to La Araucanía region ( Fig. 147 ).
Altitudinal range. From coastal to highlands ecosystems (10– 4,200 m .a.s.l.).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 134–139 .
Copestylum rufoscutellare ( Philippi, 1865 )
: (134) lateral view and (135) dorsal view, male (Photos by Vicente Valdés). Scale bars = 1.5 mm.
Copestylum saphirinum ( Bigot, 1883 )
: (136) lateral view, female (photo by Vicente Valdés). Scale bar = 2 mm.
Copestyllum scutellata ( Macquart, 1842 )
: (137) lateral view (photo by Vicente Valdés). Scale bar = 3 mm. (138) feeding on
Porlieria chilensis I. M. Johnst., Alcones
(photo by Esteban López), and (139) feeding on
Prunus
sp., Santiago (photo by Orlando Montes).

subSubSection.paragraph:
Biology and notes.
Copestylum scutellatum
is a species that has a wide distribution in the Neotropical region. In Chile , the species is found from highlands in the Puna province to Mediterranean sclerophyllous forests. Porter (1921) associated this species with the flowers of
Aristolochia chilensis
. thanks to some specimens collected by professor Stuardo in La Serena. Bastidas (1956) associates females of this species with the cactus of the genus
Opuntia
, where it deposits their eggs in groups of two or three in the thorns of high parts of the plant. It has also been observed visiting native flowers of
H. stenophyllum
(Toty Leiva, CSP record);
Porlieria chilensis (I.M. Johnst.)
(Javiera Chinga and Tomás Paulo, CSP records);
Talguenea quinquinervia (Gill et Cook) Johnst
(Ariadna Veas, CSP record);
Trevoa quinquenervia
(Daniel Llavaneras, CSP record);
B. globosa
(Fernando González, CSP record);
Encelia canescens Lam.
(Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia pers. obs.);
Baccharis
sp. (Apatama Ph, CSP record);
Acacia caven (Molina) Molina
(César Martínez, CSP record);
Q. saponaria
(César Martínez, CSP record);
Prosopis chilensis (Molina) Stuntz emend. Burkart
, and
Frankenia chilensis K. Presl.
(Rodrigo Barahona-Segovia, pers. obs.). It has also been observed visiting exotic plants such as
R. sativus
(R. Barahona-Segovia, pers. obs.);
Prunus domestica
L. (Orlando Montes, CSP record) and
E. pectinatus
(Claudia Contreras, CSP record).
Conservation status. LC; EOO = 240,950 km 2 , AOO = 244 km 2 , 45 subpopulations and 53 localities.
